summary: This is a court order from Judge Alison J. Nathan in the Ghislaine Maxwell criminal case, outlining detailed procedures for jury selection. The order addresses scheduling for juror questionnaires and voir dire, establishes protocols for juror privacy and identification by number, and denies a request to seal the proposed jury questionnaires.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case for which these jury selection procedures are being established.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the order, outlining the jury selection procedures and denying the sealing request.

events.description: Screening questionnaires for prospective jurors are administered.

events.title: Deadline for Joint Juror Lists (Nov 4-5)
events.description: Counsel must jointly submit lists categorizing prospective jurors based on questionnaire reviews.

events.description: Screening questionnaires for prospective jurors are administered.

events.title: Deadline for Joint Juror Lists (Nov 12)
events.description: Counsel must jointly submit lists categorizing prospective jurors based on questionnaire reviews.

events.title: Potential In-Person Conference
events.description: A conference scheduled at 9:30 a.m. to resolve any disputes regarding juror lists.

events.title: Voir Dire Begins
events.description: One-on-one voir dire with prospective jurors begins, to be conducted by the Court in the presence of the parties with public access.

events.title: Potential Date for Peremptory Strikes
events.description: One of two possible dates on which the exercise of peremptory strikes may proceed.

events.title: Potential Date for Peremptory Strikes
events.description: One of two possible dates on which the exercise of peremptory strikes may proceed.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court order establishes a detailed, multi-stage jury selection process for the Ghislaine Maxwell trial, acknowledging the case's significant publicity.
Jurors will be identified only by randomly assigned numbers throughout the selection process to ensure privacy and candor.
The court denied a request to seal the proposed and draft jury questionnaires and voir dire plans, citing the First Amendment right to public access.
The procedures are designed to balance juror safety during the COVID-19 pandemic, juror impartiality, and public access to the proceedings.
The order references a prior conference where the parties discussed the potential need for additional, narrowly tailored procedures during voir dire.
